I needed a stubby screwdriver for a project and I almost bought one from a hardware store...Duh! I can print one! All you need are the 1/4" hex bits which most people already have.

All parts were printed on a TOM with a MK6+. My settings were: Object infill% 65, Layer height(mm) .27, Number of shells 0, feedrate (mm/s) 32.
Print the part and install a bit.

title: Makerfarm Webcam mount for Microsoft Lifecam Show

description.text:
A webcam mount for a Microsoft Lifecam Show which attaches to the build plate of a MakerFarm i3v or Pegasus 3D printer.

The advantage of having the webcam mounted to the build plate is that the view of the part remains stationary on printers where Y axis motion is achieved by moving the build plate.

The mount is based on HoffmanEngineering's mount with variants for:

  • quarter inch (wood) or 3mm (aluminium) Y carriage; and
  • mounts with or without a stabilising arm

The brackets have also been changed from the original by reducing the mounting hole from 7mm diameter to 5.5mm; sized for an M5 bolt to attach the Lifecam Show mount.

The Lifecam Show mount is available in 15 or 30 degree angles to tune your view.
The parts were designed in OnShape, a web based CAD tool and the design available at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5750ce10e4b0634a441cf939/w/a3677fcdee38ca6707cba97e/e/ff21dd9ea263fb4ee77b6ad4.

author: welchomatic

description.text:
This is a mount for the Kindle Fire which slides out from underneath a cabinet. It's space saving, and leaves all the ports and speakers accessible. I have also included the OpenSCAD files, in case you want to make it compatible with another tablet, or you have different screws.  
Please check the instructions for how to assemble, or leave me a comment if you have questions!

In addition to the printed parts, you will need the following: 4x M4 Nylon screws
Superglue or ABS juice
2x Magnets (optional)
Hot Glue (optional) First, check the dimensions of your screws -- If you have different screws, adjust the "screw" parameter in slide.scad, then reexport. I used nylon screws for its slipperiness, but I suspect that any screw will work. Print out all the plastic parts. Ream out the holes for the screws on the clip parts, then screw your nylon screws in, leaving about 3 mm to spare. The clips should be a tight fit on the original Kindle Fire. Again, if you have a different tablet, adjust the "length", "height", and "round" parameters in clip.scad and reexport. The slides are printed in top and bottom halves -- superglue (or use abs juice if you've printed with ABS) them together. Make sure the clips slide nicely in them. If they're tighter than you like, adjust the "tol" parameter in slide.scad or recheck your screw dimensions. Using wood screws, mount the slides under your cabinet, leaving the notched portion protruding. Drop the bottom nylon screws into the notch, and you should be able to slide your tablet through the slides. Lift the front screws up over the notch, and they should fall in as well. Optionally, you can print "magnet.stl", hot glue on a cheap magnet, and another one on the back of one clip. Then hot glue it to the top of the cabinet, to prevent the tablet from swinging forward.

comments.text: I wish I could just have it as a case! It would look really cool. Boo-ho on me I guess.

I have thought of doing this but for my wacom intous 3. But with a spring loaded system instead so that it would flip up to a 30 degree angle to the table whenever needed...
Anyways, i like this design a lot as it saves a lot of space :D

description.text:
I once wanted to make a wind/water turbine to generate electricity.
but I have no wood/metal-working skills so the project failed.
but since I heard about 3d printers the idea of just printing it came to mind.
so here I designed a turbine in openSCAD. its probably not that good and I have doubts about the printability and durability .
but I hope somebody has use for it.

before it can be printed you need to add a hole for the axis or put a cylinder as axis on it that goes into a bearing.
I haven`t put that on it since I have no idea how big it will print and the measurements of a bearing are not known to me. after its printed find a source of wind/moving-water.
and mount it up and hook a generator up and hope it doesn`t break. maybe combine it with one of these:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1589
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:802

The Prusa source has set of OpenSCAD files for using LM8UU linear bearings, which have 15mm diameter and 24mm length.
Unfortunately I got set of LME8UUs, which are ALMOST the same, except that they happen to be millimeter longer and thicker than LM8UUs - 16mm diameter and 25mm length.
Trying to fit these in stock printed parts would not end well, so I hacked into bushing.scad to fix these dimensions. While doing that, I made them parametric, so that it would be possible to switch between these more easily.
Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

description.text:
Update 1/23/2018 - Made some modifications to the model to allow more space to glow, and make it easier to print.

This is a project I put together as a gift for my nephew, who loves Kirby. It's pretty straightforward to print. I used pink and yellow PLA with a very low infill setting, and painted the raised pixels on Kirby. I've found that the easiest and cheapest way to do this is with cheap black nail polish for a clean glossy look.
The two parts should fit together printed as is, but will be a tight fit.

For the light I just used a cheap LED tea light as well:

title: TAZ RAMBO + Raspberry Pi Electronics Enclosure

description.text: Update: Also take a look at the accompanying Raspberry Pi Camera Mount if you plan to remotely monitor your printer with a camera. This is a replacement for the TAZ's electronics enclosure. It mounts, cools and protects both the RAMBo to control the printer and a Raspberry Pi to run OctoPrint on. I've set mine up to power the pi directly from the 5V aux port on the RAMBO and powered the RAMBO from the 12V line instead of USB. The RAMBO is connected via a USB cable from the Pi to get its commands. The Pi has a wifi usb adapter so that I can control my printer wirelessly from anywhere. I also have a slot for the Pi camera so that you can montor your print (I'm working on an adjustable mount for the camera). I run octoprint (in the octopi distribution) on the raspberry pi. I've also added a piezo speaker to the pi so that I can get audio notifications when a print is done or when the raspberry pi comes online. I've also configured mine to send notifications to my phone upon print completion and take time-lapse videos of the prints (and soon automatically upload to youtube). This case has a simple sliding lid and is designed so that you can easily add whatever logo you want to the lid as it is a considerably smaller print than the rest of the case. It has a hole for a 40mm fan as well (powered by the RAMBo).
I leveraged using heatset m3 nuts to mount the RAMBo and the fan.  Other than that, you screw the boards in, mount the enclosure onto the side of the TAZ, connect up the wiring and go.

title: Flexible Filament Spool Holder with Ball Bearings

description.text:
Wanted to create a low friction filament spool holder that I could use flexibly with the different spools I had (different width but same diameter of 20cm).
Also wanted to use some ball bearings with a one-sided rim that I had found on Amazon.
Initially I was thinking of printing an additional base plate that would have parallel slots in different widths for my holders so that for different spools, I could just slide the holders into the predefined slots to make sure they stay in place at the same distance. Turns out this is not required as the spool sits well in the bearings inside the rims.

Note that you need to print two items of these.

title: Knob / Pointer for Bowden Extruder Stepper Motor

description.text:
A small knob/pointer to put on the stepper motor shaft of your extruder stepper motor(s). It provides an easy view of the movement of the stepper motor and filament.

I have been using these for a couple months and find them very helpful to see what the stepper motors are doing during a print. It is especially useful when multiple extruders are running.

There are two styles here; one with a flat knob face, and one with a raised pointer on the face. I printed two of the flat-face type in PLA; the first one fit like a glove onto the shaft. The second one required some filing/scraping to make it fit. If yours don't fit well, then you can scale them up slightly in Slic3r, and probably others too. Slic3r also has an adjustment that allows you to add or subtract XX mm to the X Y dimensions. Using it you can easily add 0.1 mm if it is too tight. The adjustment is located at: Print Settings / Advanced / XY Size Compensation.

Use a marker pen to make the pointer stand out, or maybe change the filament color of the raised one where the pointer starts to print.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3 Modified

As required

Standard cleanup is required.

prueba de porta lapices

In my business, I need to cut precise lengths of heat-shrink tubing, with nice clean, straight ends. I looked at all the tubing cutter designs here on Thingiverse, and the good ones all require hardware like springs and bolts. I wanted one that can use the same single-edge razor blades used in razor scrapers, and no other hardware.

WARNING: Razor blades can injure you. They should be handled with care and kept out of reach of children. Use this design at your own risk.

It is important to slice this model with settings that will prevent printer travel moves that cross over the slot where the razor blade goes. The slot is so narrow that it would be difficult to clean out any stringing there, and you might not be able to get the razor into the slot.

The red Push PLA shown in the photos tends to print fat, and then shrink while cooling, which forced me to make the blade slot pretty wide to keep it from closing up during printing. If your print ends up with the slot so wide that the blade could wobble, use narrow strips of tape on the blade, one or more layers, to fill the extra space. Use just enough tape so that the blade slides into the slot but won't come out when tilted.

Layer Height = .2mm
Perimeters = 3 minimum
Speed = 25mm/s
Travel speed = 130mm/s
Infill = 100% Concentric
No Support
Extrusion Width = .6mm (my Orion nozzle is .5mm)
Fan and retraction settings will depend upon your material.

The Backstop simply friction-fits onto the cutter at whatever distance you need.

I included the BackstopBase file so people could add their own cylindrical tube holder for whatever size tubing they need. Note that there is limited headroom with the cutter fully closed (about 9mm), so if you need to cut larger tubing you might try the "more space" version of the cutter.

description.text:
I needed a bent broom stick screw to fit over cut down wooden broom sticks..

My project required that the thread face at a certain angle, you can rotate the thread angle and add a simple ID mark to the top for reference.

This is based on the work of Ed Niesley (https://softsolder.com/2013/04/01/broom-handle-screw-thread-replacement-plug/)

Update
The "text" command in scad doesn't seem to be working in the thingiverse customizer. If this is required for your project you will have to use the external OpenSCAD. Everything else seems to work fine.

description.text:
Kite string can be convenient for tying heirloom tomato plants to a trellis but when you have a bunch of plants making all those knots for each tie up gets tedious and time consuming working with thin string and keeping tension while making the knots. This clip is designed so that all you need to do is wrap the string around the plant then take the two ends and wrap them around the clip a couple times. It has saved me time and frees me up to give the rest of my garden more attention.

Edit: Keep in mind that at the end of the year you may have a kite string mess on your hands depending on how you tie things up. GL gardening

title: E3D V6 Upgrade for Geeetech Pro-B & Similar

description.text:
I've designed a nice little extruder mount for the E3D V6 (or clone) that also allows for a fan shroud expansion and more. Clockwise extruder setup, mirror parts for anticlockwise.
I've also included redesigns of the entire X axis so you can just print this entire batch of files off for your printer.
Check out the video for more on it all and to see the actual thing on my printer.
The fan mount is for a 40mm fan, it was originally an entire shroud but there have been some complications!

https://www.3dhubs.com/edinburgh/hubs/sam

There are 2 hot end mounts:

  • Extruder Mount: for E3D V6 ripoff with longer barrel. (~69mm)
  • E3D Mount: for E3D V6 original, lower set.

title: A Simple Direct Current Electric Motor

description.text:
I recently designed this project specifically for the MakerEd Challenge 2.0.

This project explores how a basic electric motor converts electricity into movement through electromagnetic interactions. It’s a fun and safe way to demonstrate the principals of electromagnetism.

This basic direct current electric motor has been designed with simplicity and ease of construct in mind, as such there are a minimum of parts and requires no soldering. This makes it an ideal classroom or children’s project.

The project consists of only 3 printed parts (Armature, Base and Switch Lever), four 2x10mm neodymium magnets, 2 C cell batteries a spool of 0.5mm enamelled copper wire, a sewing pin, a thumbtack and 9 contacts made from 0.002 and 0.005 brass shimming.

For simplicity the armature frame of the motor is combined with the bearing shafts and commutator as a single piece. While the base of the motor combines the battery holder, switch, bearing surfaces and magnet holders into a single piece. The switch is consists of a handle and a tapered disc that pushes on a brass contact. The armature spins on two tapered bearing surfaces on the motor base, and is held in position with a slight interference fit.

The project should make an excellent teaching aid for the science of physics classroom.

https://youtu.be/l4N95VHW8mI

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

Refer to the Lesson/Activity section for the specific print settings for each part.
This started with the Idea of making a more durable classroom demonstration model for a direct current electric motor. The project was designed in 123D design and took about 8 hours to complete.

A Simple Direct Current Electric Motor Overview & Background:

This project explores how a basic electric motor converts electricity into movement through electromagnetic interactions. It’s a fun and safe way to demonstrate the principals of electromagnetism.

Objectives:

Students get hands on experience in the construction of a simple electric motor. Students will learn about magnetic repulsion and attraction, electromagnetism, and direct current circuits.

Audiences:

Year 7 to 9 science and physics students in secondary schools. No special skills or tools are required to build this project.

Subjects:

This project would be applicable to physics as well as general science classes in secondary schools.

Skills Learned:
  • The ability to follow instructions.
  • Fine motor skills.
  • Problem solving.
  • 3D printing and slicing.
  • Group work.
Lesson/Activity:

This basic direct current electric motor has been designed with simplicity and ease of construct in mind, as such there are a minimum of parts and requires no soldering. This makes it an ideal classroom or children’s project.

The project consists of only 3 printed parts, four 2x10mm neodymium magnets, 2 C cell batteries a spool of 0.5mm enamelled copper wire, a sewing pin, a thumbtack and 9 contacts made from 0.002 and 0.005 brass shimming.

For simplicity the armature frame is combined with the bearing shafts and commutator as a single piece. The armature should be printed vertically with 100% infill, supports turned on everywhere and set to a high print quality. The switch can also be printed at the same time.

The base of the motor combines the battery holder, switch, bearing surfaces and magnet holders into a single piece. When printing, good results can be achieved with no supports, 25% infill and a 0.8mm top layer thickness.

Once the base has finished printing the grooves will require cleaning out with a fine blade, the horizontal brush holder grooves will need the most attention. The armature will need the supports trimmed off with a sharp hobby knife and the bearing surfaces smoothed out with a file or fine sandpaper.

To keep things simple all the contacts in this project are made from brass shimming, it can usually be bought from arts and hobby stores quite cheaply in small assortment packs. For this project all the contacts with the exception of the brushes are made from 0.005 shimming, while the brushes are made from the thinner 0.002 shimming. If brass is difficult to come by, the fine tin from the base of a Milo can should do the trick.

Using the templates provided cut and bend the brass shimming into the required shapes. When bending the shims use a ruler or straight edge along the dotted line and bend up.

To construct the armature remove the build supports and clean out the grooves in the commutator with a thin blade. Then slide the brass commutator shims into the grooves. If the brass contacts are loose on the commutator use a dab of epoxy or super glue under the shim to hold them in place.

To wind the coil, feed the end the wire from your spool through the hollow shaft from the inside of the coil to the outside until it protrudes about 5cm from the end. Then start winding the wire around the armature frame, this is made easy by the sides of the frame being open at each end. Once the wire windings are flush to the edge of the plastic frame cut the wire generously and feed back though the hollow shaft alongside the first wire.

Cut both wires off to 3cm and bare the insulation from the first 7mm of each end with a sharp hobby knife. Then poke the wires into the small holes beside the commutator contacts, it might be necessary to clean the holes out with a hot pin before the wires will fit.

To complete the base, slide the brass shims into either end of the battery holder and switch housing. With the switch it is necessary to put a slight bend on the long brass contact so as to add a little preload onto its adjoining contact.

Cut two 12cm pieces of copper wire and a 9cm piece and scrape the insulation away from the first 7mm on all ends. Insert the bare ends of the long wires behind the battery tabs and feed through the channel as show in the picture. Poke the ends of the wires into the small provisions in the switch and brush connectors. Again it might be necessary to use a hot pin to clean out the holes beside the contacts. Use the shorter piece of wire to connect the second brush contact to the second switch contact. There should be enough tension to securely hold the wire against the brass terminals and switch contacts.

The motor uses two 2x10mm neodymium magnets stuck together on each side. They should fit snuggly into the cut-outs in the magnet holders, but a touch of glue is helpful in stopping them from vibrating during operation. The switch lever just slides down into the provision and a pin is used as the pivot. Cut the sharp end off the pin and bend using a pair of pointy nosed pliers to secure the lever.

Before installing the armature into the base it will be necessary to put a little bit of inward preload onto the brushes, this will keep them in good contact with the commutator contacts. Once that’s been done it’s a simple matter of popping the armature into the bearing blocks, this will require a little bit of force as there is a tiny but of interference to hold the armature in place.

Finally put the batteries in and flick the switch, the armature will require a gentle spin to get going. You should now have a working DC model motor. A drop of vegetable oil on each bearing will help the engine run smoother and quieter.

Once you’re happy with its operation you can use a small screw or thumbtack to attach the pinwheel to the end of the shaft.

Duration:

The project will take about 8 hours to print for all the parts. Once printed the assemble process should take no more than 2 hours as there are very few parts to assemble.

Preparation:

The parts should be

  • Printed motor base.
  • Printed switch lever.
  • Printed armature.
  • Four 2x10mm neodymium magnets.
  • 2 C cell batteries.
  • A spool of 0.5mm enamelled copper wire.
  • A sewing pin.
  • A thumbtack or screw.
  • 0.002 and 0.005 brass shimming.
  • The instruction sheet.
References:

Every good secondary school physics book will have a sufficient explanation of the forces and principals at work in the motor. However Wikipedia also has an in depth explanation at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DC_motor

Rubric & Assessment:

By the end of the project:

  • Did the student successfully print all three main components of the model?
  • Did the student assembled the project according to instructions resulting in a working DC motor?
  • Did the student experiment with changing polarities/direction of the engine?
  • Did the student Develop an understanding of the principals at work in an electric motor?
Handouts & Assets:

Included in the project is a two page handout that has instructions for completing the project and templates for the brass shims and pinwheel. The instructions should be printed double sided so that the pinwheel prints properly.

comments.text: If you are using Simplify3D you can fix the problem by going into the advanced tab in the Simplify settings, then into the "Slicing behavior" option. If you check the option "merge all outlines into a single solid model", the parts should slice correctly!

comments.text: I also own a BoXZY and am almost to the point of having to replace some of the bearings just from 3D printing alone. description.text: This is a bayonet wrist strap mount for the CycleOps Joule GPS data logger. We use this in our research to track power output and other telemetry from athlete training sessions. We use the Joule GPS in combination with the PowerCal ECG chest strap for Running sessions, and with the PowerTap rear hub attached to one of our prototype bikes for Bionic Running sessions. Printed in nylon, it is held snugly in place with a firm twisting lock - see instructions.
I printed this in nylon, and used chunky rubber wrist straps intended for a diving watch. The wrist strap pins are made from lengths of 1.75mm nylon fused in place with a soldering iron.
This is a TPU Pod based on my Horny Tucano for the Campilot Twister 210. Just that this model was adapted to fit a 2.1mm lens and a 40x40mm hole pattern as found on mixuko for example.

description.text: Scanned with The Scan-O-Tron 3000 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:127968), ReconstructMe (http://reconstructMe.net) and an Xbox Kinect at the Great Fredini's Coney Island Scan-A-Rama booth at the 2013 World Maker Faire New York. The Great Fredini's Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is the next generation portrait studio for the 21st century! In the grand tradition of amusement part portraiture, but updated for the era of 3D printing, this popup 3D portrait studio is open weekly in Coney Island and can even appear at your event. For more information or to order prints, please visit http://www.thegreatfredini.com/scan-a-rama For best results, I recommend printing at .1 mm layer height with no support. You may have to add a few little support cylinders manually, and trim a couple bits of hanging plastic off, but you will get a better result with no support.

comments.text: Hi Fredini- thank you for the Scan-a-tron scans. Really cool project. I've been cleaning up the scanning artifacts a little and choosing the scans which would print well without supports to use as architectural scale reference. If people were cool with it, it would be great to release the photo of the person as well- if I had a reference I would detail the face a little more.

I do a lot of shopping at IKEA, whether itÃ¢â¬â¢s for disposable apartment furniture or cheap mechanical parts to use for DIY projects. Whenever I leave the store I always end up with a pocket full of those little golf pencils they have all over the store. IÃ¢â¬â¢m not a collector, it just happens. Well IÃ¢â¬â¢ve decided they deserve a better life. One where they are used and not ignored because of their size in the bottom of a drawer. Time to liberate my miniature writing implements. I've created a golf pencil dispenser inspired by the straw dispensers you see in restaurants. It also has a lid to keep it tidy and holes for screws on the back so it can be wall mounted. More info and photos are available on my blog at:
http://thenewhobbyist.com/2012/01/golf-pencil-dispenser/

• Print dispenser and lid
  • (optional) hang on wall
  • fill with pencils
  • there is no step 4

  • Adrenaline
    Produced in stressful or exciting situations. Increases heart rate & blood flow, leading to a physical boost & heightened awareness.
  • Noradrenaline
    Affects attention & responding to actions in the brain, and involved in fight or flight response. Contracts blood vessels, increasing blood flow.
  • Dopamine
    Feelings of pleasure, and also addiction, movement, and motivation. People repeat behaviors that lead to dopamine release.
  • Serotonin
    Contributes to well-being & happiness. Helps sleep cycle & digestive system regulation. Affected by exercise and light exposure

description.text:
Took the bottom part of the case as a tray for the runcam and added some pillars to hold the HS1177 board camera in its case. Using this on a pan servo, I just screwed the servo arm directly on and then the hole in the bottom gives easy access to screw the arm onto the servo itself.

Use this OpenSCAD script to generate the earlobe portion of 3D printed plugs. Combine with Pac-Man(s) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16132 or Space Invaders http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5096 or Shamrocks http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19309 !

• Open "Parametric plugs.scad" in OpenSCAD

  • Measure some existing plugs using calipers

  • Change the value of PLUGS_DIAMETER to match

  • Print one at a time, or use Skeinforge's Multiply setting

  • Use a solvent to bond these to one of my designs, or your own!

print_settings.Notes:: I needed a very lightweight 3 cell AAA battery holder that would withstand vibration.  This was printed on a Printrbot Simple 1405 with Repetier & Slic3r.  Print settings are important.  2 bottom layers, zero infill, 1 vase spiral wall, zero top layers.  This will automatically generate the body and top cap ends which are not visible in the STL files.  I decided to let Slic3r generate my end caps for me.  Print one body (center), one top, and two contact holders to be assembled and inserted into the top and bottom.

title: AAA Battery Holder w/ Contacts & Leads

description.text: Lightweight, low profile, vibration resistant - 3 cell AAA battery holder.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.4mm

Infill:

none

Notes:

I needed a very lightweight 3 cell AAA battery holder that would withstand vibration. This was printed on a Printrbot Simple 1405 with Repetier & Slic3r. Print settings are important. 2 bottom layers, zero infill, 1 vase spiral wall, zero top layers. This will automatically generate the body and top cap ends which are not visible in the STL files. I decided to let Slic3r generate my end caps for me. Print one body (center), one top, and two contact holders to be assembled and inserted into the top and bottom.

Post print assembly

Drill holes just large enough for the wire leads to pass thru the body, top and both battery contact holders. Make sure the holes in the contact holders line up with the holes in the top and bottom. No soldering is required. The wires and contacts are pressure fit into the contact holders. If you run the bare wire 2mm past the end of the short contacts, they will be held in place by the contact. Contacts are made out of 0.25 x 0.018 inch brass strip that you can find at any True Value Hardware. I measured by sight, cut the strips with a wire cutter, and bent them around a small screwdriver handle. Brass strip is easy to cut and bend, but springy... making it a good contact material. After assembling each contact, insert one into the top, and bottom. Feed the wire lead thru the hole you drilled. Seat the contact flat against the bottom by pushing with a screw driver or needle nose pliers. Insert batteries, and pressure fit the top on. I leave it to you to figure out contact positions, battery directions, etc. If you're printing this, you probably understand how to wire batteries in series. You may need to adjust the scaling of either the body or top in Repetier for a tight fit. Test with your multimeter.

Opening, Closing, Seating Contacts

The top and bottom friction fit tightly. I've found the best way to open the battery holder up is to rotate the top back and forth (as if you were trying to unscrew it) while pulling. This also works pretty well if you don't get voltage, and need to tighten the cap up more. Also, in retrospect, I should have printed this in clear plastic so I could see how well the contacts and batteries were seated. If you choose a different color, a flashlight should shine thru the single wall enough to see thru the assembly.

Just another note. I'm trying to scale this for AAAA batteries also. I haven't been successful because the contact holders can't scale small enough for the 1/4 inch brass strip. I've unsuccessfully looked for more narrow strip in hardware stores and online. I can certainly cut it. I also considered copper. But, I don't know if it has sufficient springiness to maintain tight contact. And, I was really going for ease of production. So, if anyone has a good idea, let me know! Thanks. :-)

This was designed using Autodesk's 123D Design. I started the design by drawing the shape of a heart in 2D. From there, I added text on each side of the heart and matched the size to the approximate height of the heart.

Next, I extruded the faces of the heart and the letters. I added a line parallel to the bottom of the figures and revolved all of the shapes around that line.

Lastly, I added a fillet to all of the edges of the heart.

title: Filament Guide for Acrylic Geeetech I3 Pro

description.text:
This is a simple filament guide for use with Geeetech Acrylic I3 Pro, so that the filament is not dragged directly across the acrylic printer frame while printing.
It provides a much more consistent feed into the extruder as it is not only lifted up from the frame but also directed better, no matter where exactly the filament spool is located.

It is designed to use the existing lcd display screw for mounting to the top of the printer frame.

title: Raspberry Pi Zero v1.3 cast case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Two piece case with integral cooling fins. Used my Raspberry Pi reference model to make this.

The two pieces are intended to be 3d printed at 101% of the as designed size, then investment cast in aluminum. The "top" piece with the fins is designed with 75% thread engagement holes for M2.5 screws. Tap these four holes. The four holes on the bottom piece should be a close fit for an M2.5 screw.

If you want to cast it in a different metal, use the appropriate multiplier.

License for commercial reproduction can be negotiated.

Comments appreciated.

description.text:
This shim can be adjusted up to around 125% its original height using a screwdriver. Each shim requires two of the pieces printed the same size, plus a #6-32 machine screw and hex nut set of an appropriate length. See instructions for details.  
This can be used for furniture making (I developed it to fine-tune drawer slide rails), for leveling, etc.  
Version 3 adds the option of screw holes so one or both sides can be attached - may be useful for woodworking applications.

Print two of the shim pieces and put them together with the shiny sides facing each other (the side that was facing down during the print).  
Insert a #6-32 machine screw through the slot and secure with a hex nut on the other end. Try to match the size of the machine screw to the length, e.g. use 1.5 inches for the default 39mm (1.5 inch) length.  
Apologies for the unit hodgepodge but all units are currently mm (millimeters). 26mm is about 1 inch, 39mm 1.5 inches, 52mm 2 inches, etc.  
Use your regular infill setting or slightly denser. The default honeycomb fill pattern slic3r generates is actually quite strong although the print orientation slants it a bit.  
Note that when adjusting the shim the slot should allow the height to expand up to about 125% the original height. Going beyond that will have some of the machine screw sticking out and pointing down.

comments.text: I am running this off a Raspberry Pi 3 loaded with Octoprint and optionally with Repetier Server when I have my laptop nearby.  The RAMPs controller is driving the steppers and it allows me to use a USB port to control the machine.  MACH3 on the other hand, uses a parallel port and requires a different type of controller.  At one time, I had a machine that I ran with MACH 3, but I chose the MPCNC because I no longer have a computer with a parallel port and the RAMPS controller does a fine job with using Repetier software, either the server or the host and even Octoprint, although Octoprint is really too slow and harder to use.  I like Repetier Server best.  I can even run it on my MAC and that is what I use to control my Prusa 3D printer.

title: E3D V6 Bowden mount + fan duct for DaVinci 1.0A printer

description.text:
This is an evolution of this mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:846434 that fixes several shortcommings (distance of M3 screws etc.) and many other small improvements. I've also made a very nice fan duct for the 40mm stock fan!

With this mount the position and hight of the nozzle will stay the same as the stock one! For the extruder I bought a full metal version from Amazon and didn't re-use the stock parts.

I've recently designed a little cable holder as well - it is to secure the cables and give a strain relief.

If you want to use a second layer fan I've made a fan shroud for the second fan, have a look here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1634657

I've printed all three parts in one print from ABS. For orientation of the parts please refer to the picture. Choose the thinest layer settings 0.15mm or better to ease finishing. There is no need for supports, all parts will print without any support!

The E3D hotend will press fit between the two parts. The best way is to press it with a bench vise, please put a thin metal pice in the gap so it will not break during pressing the parts together.

The fan duct will be clipped on the heat sink, there is no need for any screws. In my case it got a little crack when pushing it on the first time, but a drop of super glue fixed it and now it slides on the heat sink very smooth. You may need to drill the four holes with a 2.5mm drill as the first layer usually makes the holes smaller. The M3 screws for the fan will need no nuts, they just hold into the plastic. Make sure to only gently tighten these four screws!

You will need the following extra screws:

2x M3 x 30mm + 2x M3 nuts for the mount
4x M3 x 16mm for the fan

The mount will be slided on the original carrier (no need for modification) and fixed with the two screws from the front. You can remove the complete unit just by this two screws what eases maintenance.

comments.text: Does anyone happen to know how to change the gear ratio in the repetier firmware config. I would like to put a Titan drive in along with this upgrade and realized that the gear ratio on the Titan is 3:1. (I have a bad stepper motor that I was going to replace with it) Or would it be better if I just looked for one with the same ratio?
comments.author: h2ogrifter

comments.text: Did you have to adjust the Y end stop (front to back)?  I seem to need to on mine as the fan seems to collide with the Z-Rods.
comments.author: bpislife

comments.text: @hecot how did you removed the extruder gear from the motor?
comments.author: wesk18

comments.text: The original gear is heat-shrinked on the shaft. The best way to remove it would be using a special puller - see picture enclosed! You will also need to heat up the old gear with a heat gun, so it will come loose easier. The more pragnatic way would be carefully saw a gap into the old gear and crack it with a screwdriver - it will be damaged but at least you can get it of a replace by a better quality one! Hope this helps!?
comments.author: wesk18

comments.text: I print PETG most of the time and some ABS. So honestly I've haven't tried to print flex filament as there was no need so far. A direct extruder will have some advantages compared to bowden when it comes to flex material. I've currently changed to the E3D Titan extruder that is a big advantage. Please keep me in the loop on your experiences with flex material

title: Snap lock CCD Camera Mount 38mm sq 1/3

description.text:
A simple mount for common ccd fpv camera, features a snap in fit for the ccd board ,no screws/glue required.   
printed using skeinforge/replicatorg on a duplicator, the result was a perfectly fitted snap in lock, very secure it will not fall out or move position.  
i found the 18 degree incline of camera allows for a good view of land and a high horizon (about 2/3 on 2.8mm lens) helping prevent video under exposure.  
base is intended to be glued to the model. stl file includes birdge and edge support, no raft required.

just print, no raft or support required, once printed simply insert one corner of ccd board, then push in remaining corner and check fit, if the fit is not perfectly secure adjust your scale and try again. for me perfect fit was achieved by printing to most accurate scale.

description.text:
The purpose is the same as the Ultimaker Hobbed Bolt Release by bkubicek ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14505 ).
However, I have a different kind of hobbed bolt, so his model didn't match my bolt. Also, some nuts didn't allow the holder to turn, so the knurled part is separated from the extruder and the external diameter is slightly lower to fit loosely with the extruder motor.

Print and insert the hobbed bolt head in the piece carefully. You can use a small hammer to insert the piece. With this piece and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8903 you will be able to unmount the hobbed bolt very easily to clean the plastic inside before an important print. Enjoy!:) Note: I printed it in standard quality in an Ultimaker. I used netfabb with a fill spacing of 1mm with the Standard fill profile in PLA.

Simple box for adding any types of controls you need. I'm using it to simulate signals for my Arduino projects.
Top plates 6 holes are 11 mm in diameter.
Back plates 8 holes are 8 mm in diameter.
Holes for the screws are 5 mm.
And for the lock plate the holes are 4 mm.

This is a stand used to mount anything with a hole. It is intended to be scaled as needed to fit the intended purpose. At 1.0X scale the diameter of the post is 2.85mm. For example, if you need to mount something with a 5mm hole scale the part to (5.0 / 2.85) 1.75X.

You can also use this to store things like rings, keychains etc.

title: Maker Farm Prusa I3V Titan Mount

description.text:
Update: BackCarriage-v2 has counter sunk holes for the screws in order to avoid clearance issues between the carriage and the "V" Rails.

This mount is to be used for on Maker Farm Prusa I3V.
The mount eliminates the X Carriage (Shelf) and mounts the Motor directly to the Back Carriage.

I used the "Short" Nema 17 Motor..It can be foundon amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/Short-Bipolar-Motor-18-4oz-13Ncm/dp/B00PNEQ79Q/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1465916765&sr=8-1&keywords=nema+17+short.

The mount was created to be used with Clough42 7mm Z Probe Arm and AnthonyQ's Fan Duct

The Carriage can be used with or without the Servo Mount.

Everything printed at .2 with 30% infill ABS or PET+

Titan Mount and servo Mount need very little supports.

I have printed several hours now with the new mount and extruder with no issues.

comments.text: How does the stepper mount to the back carriage plate? In the second picture it kind of looks like there is a bracket around the back of the stepper? Is this a missing .stl file? Otherwise, everything printed fine, but I just don't see how to get the extruder + motor actually mounted.
comments.author: mgsb

comments.text: The motor mounts directly to the rear plate.. You need to remove the screws from the back of the motor and replace them with longer ones that will go through the plate and into the motor. Be careful not to use to long of a screw, because you still need to mount the extruder through the front of the motor screw holes which are the same as the rear holes.
comments.author: mgsb

comments.text: do you know what size screws they are
comments.author: voodoo28

comments.text: m3 22mm flat head
comments.author: imrcly

comments.text: Thanks. I had to get some screws and file them down to get it to mount. Another question: how do you have the heat block oriented? It looks like it should be turned so that the wires (heater, thermistor) come out the back towards the x carriage, correct?
comments.author: voodoo28

comments.text: Correct the heat block has the wires from the heat cartridge pointing back. The shorterside of the heat block points towards the cooling fan
comments.author: mgsb

comments.text: See my post to the Made section - it's up and running - thanks! Any suggestions on the settings you are using for the Titan and E3Dv6? Retraction amount/speed? Print speed?

comments.text: My best suggestion would be to check on http://3dprintboard.com/forumdisplay.php?28-MakerFarm-Forum for the settings on your machine. Every machine will differ, but at least you have a starting point. I have the Prusa I3V 12", so my settings might be different then the Pegasus.

author: EngrainedProducts

description.text:
This is a teminal block that I designed more for a test than anything. Buried inside the object are five hex cavities for holding nuts (see the cut-away photo). During the print, the ToM is paused and five nuts are dropped into place. When the print continues the nuts are covered over except for the screw hole. The design places a single layer completely over the nut to assist the structure above, but it is easily punched through when the screws are installed. This produces a much stronger screw thread than tapping the plastic.
Included is the source in Alibre Design format.

This is easiest if you have the Gen-4 Interface and your firmware has been updated with jetty's interface firmware (thing 15380). Set the pause for layer at 6.350mm. Or, pause the machine manually as soon as the top layer is placed on the hold-down ears at each end.
This was designed for use with #4 hardware, but it will work fine with 3mm.

comments.text:
I printed this to use with 3mm nuts, but they rotate freely inside.
The layer on top of the nut seemed a bit thick as I had to drill it.
Still, this is clever. I might have to remix it for later use.

title: Slime Rancher - Pink Slime, Tabby Slime and Rock Slime

description.text:
Watch here: https://youtu.be/8mUZwurizkc
And subscribe if you like what you see! I make new 3D models every week. :)

These are some Slimes from Slime Rancher. It's a PC game on Steam and it's really fun. There are a lot of slimes but I decided to go with the Pink Slime, Tabby Slime and the Rock Slime. I'll do more in the future if you guys like them.

I created the models in Fusion 360 using their sculpting tools. Then I printed them out on my Robo3D. They took about 4 hours to model and about 8 hours to print. I even printed a base for all of them to sit on.

Post Processing:
My wife followed the usual steps while finishing these prints up. She sanded and cleaned them up a bit. Then applied some primer before painting them. She painted the main colors with an airbrush and the painted on the details using a paintbrush and acrylic paints.

Fusion 360: http://autode.sk/1s0ABZA

Printer: Robo3D R1
Filament: White Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm

comments.text:
This is a really good design.
I have a thought, though.
I think that printing the pins with horizontal layers makes slight differences in thickness that can interfere with motion through the pin bed.
I might try printing the pins separately with vertical layers.
If there is any improvement, I'll post the findings.

title: No Glue! Curio Display for Miniatures 25mm to 32mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Today I am releasing CAD files to cut 4 curio displays for 25-32mm miniatures of various size. Each curio is fitted for a certain size and should contain 3 cell variations. The design is so tight that no glue will be required, just smack the parts together with a rubber mallet. I have released a half size demo here, all 4 full size curio designs are available for download at www.timeportalgames.com with simple email registration. You will need a laser cutter with a 12x20 work area or larger and 1/8 inch baltic birch with a true thickness around 0.112 .

author: GameScape3D

description.text:
I added 2 inches to the standard MPCNC C-NutLock to raise my tool holder to better support the router motor I am using.

Drill the holes 2" from the existing holes in the EMT tubes for your Z gantry and use 2 of these extended nut traps to raise your tool holder.

I wanted to build an fpv pod using parts I had on hand, this pod uses a micro ccd camera (http://www.banggood.com/600TVL-8_0MP-14-2_8mm-CMOS-FPV-170-Degree-Wide-Anlge-Lens-Camera-PALNTSC-p-984345.html).

It should be able to fit a variety of smaller VTX transmitters, I used this VTX (http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-TS5840-Upgraded-40CH-5_8G-200mW-Wireless-AV-Transmitter-TX-for-FPV-Multicopter-p-1033810.html). I drilled the whole I ran my RX antenna through.

Big thanks to TheMultirotorShop for the frame.

title: The Coiler [gear version] (for clapton and juggernaut coils) - Vape Mod

description.text:
This is a different version of this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1611185
Someone requested me a version with gear and not orings/elastic like the other so here is.

With this completely manual tool u can built your preferred coil.

With this u can do:

  • a classic clapton coil;
  • a juggernaut coil.

About the print STL named with _x2 final u have to print double.

To mount u need:

  • 2x M3x15 (with nuts) for crankshaft;
  • 2x M3x10 for wire fixing;
  • 1x M3x15 for knob mounting.

It's easy to print and mount. I suggest to fix it in a plane using the 4 hole or a clamp.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1mygAkOECdc

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UdjtKA5PvjI
